p: Pinus roxburghii Sarg, belonging to family Pinaceae, is commonly named by “Chir pine” and is native to the Himalaya. It exists as a large ornamental tree nearly 30–50 m high possessing a trunk of about 2 m in diameter. It is found at 500 to 2500 m above the sea level growing gregariously [ 5]. Traditionally, it was widely employed as an antiseptic, diaphoretic, and a diuretic agent, in addition to exerting tonic and pronounced vermifuge and rubefacient activities [ 6, 7]. The oil of the plant was greatly utilized in various herbal preparation for relieving inflammatory disorders [ 5].
